message.content:
Analyze the SPLICE CEP extension manifest.xml and configuration for any issues that could cause EvalScript errors:

1. Check the manifest.xml at /Users/imorgado/SPLICE/splice-cep/CSXS/manifest.xml for:
   - CSXS version compatibility (RequiredRuntime)
   - Host version ranges for PPRO
   - ScriptPath configuration
   - Any missing or incorrect settings

2. Check if there are any issues with the CSInterface.js at /Users/imorgado/SPLICE/splice-cep/panel/js/CSInterface.js

3. Check the jsx bridge code in /Users/imorgado/SPLICE/splice-cep/panel/js/config.js (the jsx object around line 74)

4. Compare with working CEP extension examples to find any configuration differences

Report any issues found and suggest fixes.

file.content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<ExtensionManifest xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
                   ExtensionBundleId="com.splice.panel"
                   ExtensionBundleVersion="6.0.3"
                   Version="7.0">

    <ExtensionList>
        <Extension Id="com.splice.panel.main" Version="6.0.3"/>
    </ExtensionList>

    <ExecutionEnvironment>
        <HostList>
            <Host Name="PPRO" Version="[24.0,99.9]"/>
        </HostList>
        <LocaleList>
            <Locale Code="All"/>
        </LocaleList>
        <RequiredRuntimeList>
            <RequiredRuntime Name="CSXS" Version="11.0"/>
        </RequiredRuntimeList>
    </ExecutionEnvironment>

    <DispatchInfoList>
        <Extension Id="com.splice.panel.main">
            <DispatchInfo>
                <Resources>
                    <MainPath>./panel/index.html</MainPath>
                    <ScriptPath>./jsx/hostScript.jsx</ScriptPath>
                    <CEFCommandLine>
                        <Parameter>--allow-file-access</Parameter>
                        <Parameter>--allow-file-access-from-files</Parameter>
                        <Parameter>--enable-nodejs</Parameter>
                        <Parameter>--mixed-context</Parameter>
                    </CEFCommandLine>
                </Resources>
                <AccessList>
                    <URLAccess>
                        <URL>https://splice-api-production.up.railway.app</URL>
                        <URL>https://spliceclips.com</URL>
                        <URL>https://splice.video</URL>
                    </URLAccess>
                </AccessList>
                <Lifecycle>
                    <AutoVisible>true</AutoVisible>
                </Lifecycle>
                <UI>
                    <Type>Panel</Type>
                    <Menu>SPLICE - AI Video Editor</Menu>
                    <Geometry>
                        <Size>
                            <Height>800</Height>
                            <Width>400</Width>
                        </Size>
                        <MinSize>
                            <Height>400</Height>
                            <Width>300</Width>
                        </MinSize>
                        <MaxSize>
                            <Height>2000</Height>
                            <Width>800</Width>
                        </MaxSize>
                    </Geometry>
                    <Icons>
                        <Icon Type="Normal">./panel/icons/icon-light.png</Icon>
                        <Icon Type="DarkNormal">./panel/icons/icon-dark.png</Icon>
                    </Icons>
                </UI>
            </DispatchInfo>
        </Extension>
    </DispatchInfoList>
</ExtensionManifest>

Based on my search results, here's what I found about CEP extension manifest.xml, EvalScript errors, RequiredRuntime CSXS versions, and Adobe 2025:

## CEP Extension manifest.xml Structure

Except for the required CSXS folder, which must contain manifest.xml, the folder structure is flexible. The /CSXS folder contains the manifest.xml file, which stores the extension configuration data.

## RequiredRuntime CSXS Versions

The `RequiredRuntime` element in manifest.xml specifies which CEP version your extension requires:

- RequiredRuntime defines a version of CEP for your extension to use.
- For newer Adobe 2025 applications, you can use Version="12.0" for both the ExtensionManifest Version and RequiredRuntime CSXS Version.

Example manifest structure with CSXS version 12.0 (for Adobe 2025 apps):
```xml
<RequiredRuntimeList>
    <RequiredRuntime Name="CSXS" Version="12.0" />
</RequiredRuntimeList>
```

For CEP 11.x (Adobe 2021-2024 apps), use Version="11.0".

## EvalScript Error Troubleshooting

"Be aware that with HTML Panels a typo in the JSX makes the whole thing fail silently". One solution was removing the manifest reference to an empty jsx file, after which the panel functioned correctly.(no content)Another common cause: if the script is executed immediately when the CEP panel starts, the panel may not yet be properly initialized and ready to eval scripts. Try running the code when a button is clicked instead.

## Using evalScript

To access Application DOM from CEP extensions, CEP JavaScript library provides an API, `CSInterface.evalScript`, to execute extend script to access the host application's DOM.(no content)The script in evalScript and the jsx file configured in `<ScriptPath>` in the extension's manifest are executed in host application's ExtendScript engine, which runs in host application's main thread.

## Debug Mode Setup

For CSXS.X (where X depends on the Adobe Application version), add a new registry entry PlayerDebugMode of type string with the value of 1 to enable unsigned extensions.

For CSXS 11, you would set the registry/plist key for `CSXS.11`, and for CSXS 12 (Adobe 2025), use `CSXS.12`.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about CEP extension manifest.xml, EvalScript errors, RequiredRuntime CSXS versions, and Adobe 2025:

## CEP Extension manifest.xml Structure

Except for the required CSXS folder, which must contain manifest.xml, the folder structure is flexible. The /CSXS folder contains the manifest.xml file, which stores the extension configuration data.

## RequiredRuntime CSXS Versions

The `RequiredRuntime` element in manifest.xml specifies which CEP version your extension requires:

- RequiredRuntime defines a version of CEP for your extension to use.
- For newer Adobe 2025 applications, you can use Version="12.0" for both the ExtensionManifest Version and RequiredRuntime CSXS Version.

Example manifest structure with CSXS version 12.0 (for Adobe 2025 apps):
```xml
<RequiredRuntimeList>
    <RequiredRuntime Name="CSXS" Version="12.0" />
</RequiredRuntimeList>
```

For CEP 11.x (Adobe 2021-2024 apps), use Version="11.0".

## EvalScript Error Troubleshooting

"Be aware that with HTML Panels a typo in the JSX makes the whole thing fail silently". One solution was removing the manifest reference to an empty jsx file, after which the panel functioned correctly.(no content)Another common cause: if the script is executed immediately when the CEP panel starts, the panel may not yet be properly initialized and ready to eval scripts. Try running the code when a button is clicked instead.

## Using evalScript

To access Application DOM from CEP extensions, CEP JavaScript library provides an API, `CSInterface.evalScript`, to execute extend script to access the host application's DOM.(no content)The script in evalScript and the jsx file configured in `<ScriptPath>` in the extension's manifest are executed in host application's ExtendScript engine, which runs in host application's main thread.

## Debug Mode Setup

For CSXS.X (where X depends on the Adobe Application version), add a new registry entry PlayerDebugMode of type string with the value of 1 to enable unsigned extensions.

For CSXS 11, you would set the registry/plist key for `CSXS.11`, and for CSXS 12 (Adobe 2025), use `CSXS.12`.

content.text: Let me fetch the official Adobe CEP Samples manifest.xml for Premiere Pro to compare:

input.prompt: Extract the full manifest.xml content including RequiredRuntime version, Host version ranges for PPRO, ScriptPath configuration, and CEFCommandLine parameters

content.content:
# Premiere Pro Extension Manifest Summary

**RequiredRuntime Version:**
CSXS Runtime version 6.0 is specified as the required runtime environment.

**Host Version Range:**
The manifest targets "PPRO" (Premiere Pro) with a minimum version of 9.0.

**ScriptPath Configuration:**
The extension script is located at `"./PProPanel.jsx"` relative to the manifest directory.

**CEFCommandLine Parameters:**
Three Chromium Embedded Framework parameters are configured:
- `--allow-file-access`
- `--allow-file-access-from-files`
- `--allow-running-insecure-content`

These parameters grant the panel extended file system permissions and enable insecure content rendering.

**Additional Details:**
The extension creates a dockable panel (180×300 pixels) with the menu label "PProPanel (SDK sample panel)" that loads `./index.html` as its main interface. AutoVisible is enabled, making the panel visible by default.

# Premiere Pro Extension Manifest Summary

**RequiredRuntime Version:**
CSXS Runtime version 6.0 is specified as the required runtime environment.

**Host Version Range:**
The manifest targets "PPRO" (Premiere Pro) with a minimum version of 9.0.

**ScriptPath Configuration:**
The extension script is located at `"./PProPanel.jsx"` relative to the manifest directory.

**CEFCommandLine Parameters:**
Three Chromium Embedded Framework parameters are configured:
- `--allow-file-access`
- `--allow-file-access-from-files`
- `--allow-running-insecure-content`

These parameters grant the panel extended file system permissions and enable insecure content rendering.

**Additional Details:**
The extension creates a dockable panel (180×300 pixels) with the menu label "PProPanel (SDK sample panel)" that loads `./index.html` as its main interface. AutoVisible is enabled, making the panel visible by default.

Based on my search results, I found several relevant discussions about CEP CSInterface.js evalScript errors with JSX ScriptPath not loading in Adobe Premiere Pro. Here's what I discovered:

## Common Causes and Solutions for EvalScript Errors

### 1. New World Scripting Issue (Premiere Pro 14.0.2+)
As mentioned elsewhere, 14.0.2 defaults New World scripting to ON. #include directives don't work in New World.(no content)Instead, you can follow the usage in the PProPanel sample (see /PProPanel/PProPanel.jsx); upon panel launch, it evaluates (opens) all .jsx files used within the panel.(no content)Users have been using #include for importing json2.min.js since JSON is not available by default in ExtendScript. Didn't know about New World. Will change to evalFile now to load json2.min.js at runtime on initialization with absolute path.

### 2. JSX File Syntax Errors
"Be aware that with HTML Panels a typo in the JSX makes the whole thing fail silently." So I removed the manifest reference to my empty jsx file and the panel now functions.

### 3. ScriptPath Configuration
ScriptPath: Path to your index.jsx. Make sure the path to this file is from the top level directory of your code base.

### 4. Loading JSX Files Properly
At beginning of CEP's JavaScript, it is loading JSX as following: `csInterface.evalScript('$.evalFile("' + fullpath_fileName + '")')`.

### 5. Common Debugging Approach
Another issue I was facing is I am unable to run extendscript in jsx file from the main.js file. The pathing is correct and I have also set the PlayerDebugMode to 1 in Registry Editor. There is no proper error message, it just says EvalScript Error and I am unable to Debug it.

### Recommended Solutions:
1. **Use evalFile instead of #include** - Replace `#include` directives with `$.evalFile()` calls
2. **Check JSX syntax** - Any typo in JSX files can cause silent failures
3. **Use PProPanel sample as reference** - If UXP won't yet work, then PProPanel is the right starting point.
4. CEP = Chromium instances which load (JavaScript-based) web pages. CEP uses the CSInterface to send ExtendScript to PPro's ExtendScript (yes, ES3) interpreter.
5. The CSInterface.evalScript function does not return the value. It is intended to be an asynchronous call. Instead, the callback you pass to evalScript is passed the value returned from the ExtendScript-side function.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

toolUseResult.query: CEP CSInterface.js evalScript error JSX ScriptPath not loading Adobe Premiere Pro

results:
Based on my search results, I found several relevant discussions about CEP CSInterface.js evalScript errors with JSX ScriptPath not loading in Adobe Premiere Pro. Here's what I discovered:

## Common Causes and Solutions for EvalScript Errors

### 1. New World Scripting Issue (Premiere Pro 14.0.2+)
As mentioned elsewhere, 14.0.2 defaults New World scripting to ON. #include directives don't work in New World.(no content)Instead, you can follow the usage in the PProPanel sample (see /PProPanel/PProPanel.jsx); upon panel launch, it evaluates (opens) all .jsx files used within the panel.(no content)Users have been using #include for importing json2.min.js since JSON is not available by default in ExtendScript. Didn't know about New World. Will change to evalFile now to load json2.min.js at runtime on initialization with absolute path.

### 2. JSX File Syntax Errors
"Be aware that with HTML Panels a typo in the JSX makes the whole thing fail silently." So I removed the manifest reference to my empty jsx file and the panel now functions.

### 3. ScriptPath Configuration
ScriptPath: Path to your index.jsx. Make sure the path to this file is from the top level directory of your code base.

### 4. Loading JSX Files Properly
At beginning of CEP's JavaScript, it is loading JSX as following: `csInterface.evalScript('$.evalFile("' + fullpath_fileName + '")')`.

### 5. Common Debugging Approach
Another issue I was facing is I am unable to run extendscript in jsx file from the main.js file. The pathing is correct and I have also set the PlayerDebugMode to 1 in Registry Editor. There is no proper error message, it just says EvalScript Error and I am unable to Debug it.

### Recommended Solutions:
1. **Use evalFile instead of #include** - Replace `#include` directives with `$.evalFile()` calls
2. **Check JSX syntax** - Any typo in JSX files can cause silent failures
3. **Use PProPanel sample as reference** - If UXP won't yet work, then PProPanel is the right starting point.
4. CEP = Chromium instances which load (JavaScript-based) web pages. CEP uses the CSInterface to send ExtendScript to PPro's ExtendScript (yes, ES3) interpreter.
5. The CSInterface.evalScript function does not return the value. It is intended to be an asynchronous call. Instead, the callback you pass to evalScript is passed the value returned from the ExtendScript-side function.

input.prompt: Extract the specific solution for EvalScript error on Premiere Pro 14.0.2, particularly about New World scripting and #include directives

content.content:
# Solution for EvalScript Error on Premiere Pro 14.0.2

## The Issue

According to Bruce Bullis (Adobe Employee), the problem stems from a significant change in Premiere Pro 14.0.2:

> "14.0.2 defaults New World scripting to ON. #include directives don't work in New World."

## The Fix

Instead of using `#include` directives for loading external scripts, developers should adopt the approach demonstrated in the PProPanel sample. The recommended solution involves:

**Load all .jsx files at panel initialization using `evalFile()` with absolute paths**, rather than relying on preprocessor directives.

This means:
- Replace `#include` statements with runtime file evaluation
- Load required files (like json2.min.js) when the CEP panel launches
- Use absolute file paths for reliable script loading

This approach aligns with New World scripting requirements and resolves the "EvalScript error" that appeared after upgrading to 14.0.2 or later versions.

toolUseResult.result:
# Solution for EvalScript Error on Premiere Pro 14.0.2

## The Issue

According to Bruce Bullis (Adobe Employee), the problem stems from a significant change in Premiere Pro 14.0.2:

> "14.0.2 defaults New World scripting to ON. #include directives don't work in New World."

## The Fix

Instead of using `#include` directives for loading external scripts, developers should adopt the approach demonstrated in the PProPanel sample. The recommended solution involves:

**Load all .jsx files at panel initialization using `evalFile()` with absolute paths**, rather than relying on preprocessor directives.

This means:
- Replace `#include` statements with runtime file evaluation
- Load required files (like json2.min.js) when the CEP panel launches
- Use absolute file paths for reliable script loading

This approach aligns with New World scripting requirements and resolves the "EvalScript error" that appeared after upgrading to 14.0.2 or later versions.

content.text: Now I have enough information to provide a comprehensive analysis. Let me also check the browser-simulation.js file quickly:

Now I have all the information needed. Let me provide a comprehensive analysis.

---

## Bug Summary

Analysis of the SPLICE CEP extension configuration for EvalScript errors.

---

## Issues Found

### 1. CRITICAL: Custom CSInterface.js Implementation Missing Key Features

**File:** `/Users/imorgado/SPLICE/splice-cep/panel/js/CSInterface.js`

The SPLICE extension uses a **custom minimal implementation** of CSInterface.js instead of Adobe's official library. This custom version is missing several important features:

**Missing from custom implementation:**
- `loadExtendScript()` method - used to load JSX files at runtime
- `getNetworkPreferences()` method
- `closeExtension()` proper implementation
- Event constants (CSXSWindowEvents, ContextMenuItemStatus, etc.)
- `SystemPath` constants (proper enum values)

**Risk:** The minimal implementation works for basic operations but may fail for more complex CEP interactions.

**Recommendation:** Replace with Adobe's official CSInterface.js from [Adobe-CEP/CEP-Resources](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/CEP-Resources/tree/master/CEP_11.x/CSInterface).

---

### 2. POTENTIAL ISSUE: Host Version Range May Be Too Restrictive

**File:** `/Users/imorgado/SPLICE/splice-cep/CSXS/manifest.xml` (Line 13)

```xml
<Host Name="PPRO" Version="[24.0,99.9]"/>
```

This targets Premiere Pro v24.0+ (2024+). If users have older versions like Premiere Pro 2023 (v23.x), the extension will not load.

**Recommendation:** Consider expanding the version range if backward compatibility is needed:
```xml
<Host Name="PPRO" Version="[22.0,99.9]"/>
```

---

### 3. CSXS Version 11.0 Compatibility

**File:** `/Users/imorgado/SPLICE/splice-cep/CSXS/manifest.xml` (Line 19)

```xml
<RequiredRuntime Name="CSXS" Version="11.0"/>
```

This is correct for Adobe 2021-2024 applications. However, for Adobe 2025 applications, you may need CSXS Version 12.0. The current configuration should work but may need updates for newer Adobe versions.

---

### 4. Missing `--disable-web-security` CEFCommandLine Parameter

**File:** `/Users/imorgado/SPLICE/splice-cep/CSXS/manifest.xml` (Lines 29-34)

Current CEFCommandLine:
```xml
<CEFCommandLine>
    <Parameter>--allow-file-access</Parameter>
    <Parameter>--allow-file-access-from-files</Parameter>
    <Parameter>--enable-nodejs</Parameter>
    <Parameter>--mixed-context</Parameter>
</CEFCommandLine>
```

**Missing:** Some CEP extensions include `--disable-site-isolation-trials` for better compatibility.

---

### 5. JSX Bridge Error Handling Could Mask Root Cause

**File:** `/Users/imorgado/SPLICE/splice-cep/panel/js/config.js` (Lines 141-149)

```javascript
// Check for EvalScript error or ExtendScript runtime errors
if (typeof result === 'string' && (
    result.indexOf('EvalScript error') !== -1 ||
    result.indexOf('Error:') !== -1 ||
    result.indexOf('TypeError:') !== -1 ||
    result.indexOf('ReferenceError:') !== -1
)) {
    reject(new Error(result));
    return;
}
```

This error detection is good, but "EvalScript error" typically indicates one of these root causes:

1. **JSX file not loaded:** The ScriptPath in manifest.xml points to `./jsx/hostScript.jsx`, but if this file fails to load, all evalScript calls will fail silently.

2. **Syntax error in JSX:** A typo in the ExtendScript makes the whole file fail silently ([Adobe Community discussion](https://community.adobe.com/t5/after-effects/cep-hello-world-returns-quot-evalscript-error-quot/m-p/9366081)).

3. **New World Scripting (Premiere Pro 14.0.2+):** `#include` directives don't work in New World scripting mode ([Adobe Community solution](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro/evalscript-error-on-premiere-pro-14-0-2/td-p/10946333)).

---

### 6. ScriptPath Relative Path Format

**File:** `/Users/imorgado/SPLICE/splice-cep/CSXS/manifest.xml` (Line 28)

```xml
<ScriptPath>./jsx/hostScript.jsx</ScriptPath>
```

The path uses `./` which should work, but some CEP implementations prefer paths relative to the extension root without the leading `./`:
```xml
<ScriptPath>jsx/hostScript.jsx</ScriptPath>
```

---

### 7. The hostScript.jsx Has No Obvious Syntax Errors

**File:** `/Users/imorgado/SPLICE/splice-cep/jsx/hostScript.jsx`

The JSX file appears syntactically correct with:
- Proper ES3 syntax (required for ExtendScript)
- No `#include` directives (good for New World scripting)
- Proper JSON.stringify usage for return values
- Initialization call at the end (`initialise()`)

However, there's one potential issue - the file ends with:
```javascript
// Initialize on load
initialise();
```

This runs automatically when the JSX is loaded via ScriptPath. If there's any error during `initialise()`, the entire JSX file will fail to load and all subsequent evalScript calls will return "EvalScript error".

---

## Trace Path (If EvalScript Errors Occur)

1. **Error manifests:** `evalScript()` callback receives "EvalScript error" string
2. **Possible causes:**
   - JSX file failed to load at all (ScriptPath issue)
   - JSX file has syntax error (ExtendScript ES3 strict)
   - `initialise()` function threw an error on startup
   - Function being called doesn't exist (typo in function name)
   - Premiere Pro version mismatch with manifest Host version

---

## Recommended Fixes

### Fix 1: Use Official CSInterface.js

Replace the custom CSInterface.js with Adobe's official version:

```bash
curl -o /Users/imorgado/SPLICE/splice-cep/panel/js/CSInterface.js \
  https://raw.githubusercontent.com/AdobeXD/CEP-Resources/master/CEP_11.x/CSInterface.js
```

### Fix 2: Add JSX Loading Verification

Add diagnostic code to verify the JSX file loaded correctly. In `/Users/imorgado/SPLICE/splice-cep/panel/js/config.js`, add a verification function:

```javascript
/**
 * Verify JSX host script is loaded correctly
 * Call this on panel startup to diagnose EvalScript issues
 */
async function verifyJSXLoaded() {
    try {
        const version = await jsx.evalScript('getVersion()');
        console.log('[JSX] Host script loaded, version:', version);
        return { loaded: true, version: version };
    } catch (err) {
        console.error('[JSX] Host script NOT loaded:', err.message);
        // Try to diagnose why
        console.error('[JSX] This typically means:');
        console.error('  1. ScriptPath in manifest.xml is incorrect');
        console.error('  2. Syntax error in hostScript.jsx');
        console.error('  3. initialise() function failed on startup');
        return { loaded: false, error: err.message };
    }
}
```

### Fix 3: Add Defensive Initialization to hostScript.jsx

Wrap the initialization in a try-catch in `/Users/imorgado/SPLICE/splice-cep/jsx/hostScript.jsx`:

```javascript
// Initialize on load (with error protection)
try {
    initialise();
} catch (initErr) {
    $.writeln('[SPLICE] CRITICAL: Initialization failed: ' + initErr.message);
    // Don't throw - allow individual functions to still work
}
```

---

## Prevention

1. **Add JSX validation to build process:** Create a simple JSX syntax checker that runs before packaging
2. **Add debug logging:** The hostScript.jsx uses `$.writeln()` which outputs to Premiere Pro's console (Window > Console)
3. **Use Adobe's debug tools:** Set `PlayerDebugMode` to `1` in registry/plist for your CSXS version to enable unsigned extensions and debug features

---

## Sources

- [Adobe CEP Getting Started Guides](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Getting-Started-guides)
- [Adobe CEP PProPanel Sample manifest.xml](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/blob/master/PProPanel/CSXS/manifest.xml)
- [CEP 11.1 HTML Extension Cookbook](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/CEP-Resources/blob/master/CEP_11.x/Documentation/CEP%2011.1%20HTML%20Extension%20Cookbook.md)
- [EvalScript error solution for Premiere Pro 14.0.2](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro/evalscript-error-on-premiere-pro-14-0-2/td-p/10946333)
- [CEP hello world returns EvalScript error](https://community.adobe.com/t5/after-effects/cep-hello-world-returns-quot-evalscript-error-quot/m-p/9366081)
